newsitem.title: USA: Quaker Oats sees Q3 restructuring charge.
newsitem.headline: Quaker Oats sees Q3 restructuring charge.

text.p: Quaker Oats Co said Thursday it expects to take a third-quarter pretax restructuring charge of $37 million as part of a move to consolidate its U.S. food supply chain.
The charge relates chiefly to closing a rice-cake plant in Gridley, Calif.

In May, Quaker said, its board approved plans for an additional $12 million pretax charge that was taken in the second quarter for manufacturing consolidations in the Brazilian pasta business and the closing of an international office in Singapore.

Of the total $49 million in pretax charges, $40 million is non-cash, representing asset write-offs or disposals. As a result of these restructuring actions, Quaker said it expects to save an estimated $13 million annually.
Quaker said it expects restructuring could result in total 1997 pretax charges between $70 million and $100 million.

"These major restructuring actions are part of the ongoing program we announced April 23 to reduce our overhead costs and drive further efficiencies," chairman William Smithburg said in a statement. "These changes further improve the operating returns from the strongest portfolio of brands in Quaker's history."
Quaker's brands include Gatorade sports drink; Quaker, Cap'n Crunch and Life cereals; and Rice-A-Roni, Pasta Roni and Near East side dishes.
In April, Quaker said it was reviewing the sale of non-core businesses and potential restructuring of certain international operations.

Quaker said at the time it was working on overhead cost reductions with a goal of cutting costs by $30 million over an 18-month period, in additional to removing or absorbing costs related to Snapple, the beverage business that it sold recently.
Quaker has also begun a search for a replacement for Smithburg, who has said he hopes to retire within a year.
